<ce:figure id="fig5">

<ce:caption>

<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is linked together by hydrogen bonds to form two-dimensional network.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  The binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2) is linked together by hydrogen bonds to form two-dimensional network.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig6">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The data were assessed by dividing the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the closed aperture configuration by the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the open aperture configuration. The black dots are the experimental data, and the solids curve is the theoretical fit. (a) The self-focusing effects of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in 5.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution at 532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. (b) The self-focusing effects of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in 4.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution at 532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  The data were assessed by dividing the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the closed aperture configuration by the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the open aperture configuration. The black dots are the experimental data, and the solids curve is the theoretical fit. (a) The self-focusing effects of 1 in 5.89×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution at 532nm. (b) The self-focusing effects of 2 in 4.92×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution at 532nm.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

One-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2) were prepared based on linear and angular bipyridine ligands, respectively. Third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2in DMF solution show that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively. And the result shows that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two bis(pyridyl) ligands: <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba) and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (bpit) have been designed and synthesized. Self-assembly of the linear ligand bpba and angular ligand bpit with HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> results in a one-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpba)]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.5CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and a binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpit)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the linear ligand bpba is in transoid conformation, while in the crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> the angular ligand bpit coordinates with HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in cisoid conformation, the different geometries of the two ligands attribute to forming the dissimilar frameworks of two HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts. The determination of third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in DMF solution shows that adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic> values of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are calculated to be 2.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−29</ce:sup> and 3.24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−29</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>esu, respectively, which are comparable to those of some NLO materials. And the result indicates that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two bis(pyridyl) ligands: N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (bpit) have been designed and synthesized. Self-assembly of the linear ligand bpba and angular ligand bpit with HgI2 results in a one-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and a binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that in the crystal structure of 1 the linear ligand bpba is in transoid conformation, while in the crystal structure of 2 the angular ligand bpit coordinates with HgI2 in cisoid conformation, the different geometries of the two ligands attribute to forming the dissimilar frameworks of two HgI2 adducts. The determination of third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2 in DMF solution shows that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are calculated to be 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively, which are comparable to those of some NLO materials. And the result indicates that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Recently, metallosupramolecule species with interesting structures and topology has become one of the most active areas of material science and chemical research , because of their potential applications on magnetism, electrical conductivity, ion exchange, separation and catalysis . Usually, the network of supramolecule complex can be predicted by selecting the chemical structure of organic ligands and the appropriate coordination geometry of central metals . Especially, the structure properties of spacing ligands, such as rigidity, flexibility, lengths, sizes, bulk, linear or nonlinear geometries and isomerisation, play a particularly important role in the construction of specific architectures . Among the organic bridging blocks, bis(pyridyl) ligands are often used in the construction of metal-containing macromolecules as light-harvesting complexes and photonic materials due to their potential in supramolecule assemblies and their photophysical and redox properties, molecular devices, etc. . And so far, a variety of discrete and a wide range of infinite solid-state coordination architectures based on this kind of bis(pyridyl) ligands have been generated by chemists .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, metallosupramolecule species with interesting structures and topology has become one of the most active areas of material science and chemical research , because of their potential applications on magnetism, electrical conductivity, ion exchange, separation and catalysis . Usually, the network of supramolecule complex can be predicted by selecting the chemical structure of organic ligands and the appropriate coordination geometry of central metals . Especially, the structure properties of spacing ligands, such as rigidity, flexibility, lengths, sizes, bulk, linear or nonlinear geometries and isomerisation, play a particularly important role in the construction of specific architectures . Among the organic bridging blocks, bis(pyridyl) ligands are often used in the construction of metal-containing macromolecules as light-harvesting complexes and photonic materials due to their potential in supramolecule assemblies and their photophysical and redox properties, molecular devices, etc. . And so far, a variety of discrete and a wide range of infinite solid-state coordination architectures based on this kind of bis(pyridyl) ligands have been generated by chemists .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">On the other hand, mercuric iodide, on the basis of its physical and electronic properties, has also been the focus of many studies. Its most distinguishing features, high density (6.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) and high average atomic numbers of the constituent elements (80 and 53), result in a very large photoelectric effect and a high full-energy peak efficiency, especially at higher γ-ray energies . These features make it useful in the fields such as optical detector  and superconducting materials . Additionally, mercury together with the iodine is relatively heavy, which may bring better NLO effects .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, mercuric iodide, on the basis of its physical and electronic properties, has also been the focus of many studies. Its most distinguishing features, high density (6.3gcm-3) and high average atomic numbers of the constituent elements (80 and 53), result in a very large photoelectric effect and a high full-energy peak efficiency, especially at higher γ-ray energies . These features make it useful in the fields such as optical detector  and superconducting materials . Additionally, mercury together with the iodine is relatively heavy, which may bring better NLO effects .

elements.clean_text: Based on the above considerations, and in order to further develop our understanding the construction of metal-based supramolecules and investigate the relationship between structures and properties, we synthesized two bis(pyridyl)-based bridging ligands, N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (bpit) ( ). Based on the two ligands, one-dimensional zigzag chain polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2) were obtained and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, their third NLO properties in DMF solution were also determined.

Infrared spectra were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> using the KBr pellet technique. elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

All were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer in the range of 400-4000cm-1 using the KBr pellet technique. Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were carried out on a Carlo-Erba 1106 Elemental Analyzer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of ligands</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of N,N′-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was directly dissolved in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The mixture was refluxing until the white powder dissolved completely. And the residue SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was moved away under reduced pressure. The resultant 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acyl chloride was dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml dry pyridine. Then, the pyridine solution of 4-aminopyridine (1.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dropwise added into the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylicacyl chloride under stirring in the ice bath. Continuously stirring for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h resulted in white precipitates. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The dried production weighs 1.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (yield 60%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 67.91; H, 4.43; N, 17.60. Found: C, 67.54; H, 4.61; N, 17.39%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3442(s), 1683(s), 1507(m), 1424(s), 1285(s), 1110(w), 937(w), 878(w), 777(m), 729(m).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of ligands

Synthesis of N,N'-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba)

1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.66g, 10mmol) was directly dissolved in 20ml SOCl2. The mixture was refluxing until the white powder dissolved completely. And the residue SOCl2 was moved away under reduced pressure. The resultant 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acyl chloride was dissolved in 10ml dry pyridine. Then, the pyridine solution of 4-aminopyridine (1.90g, 20mmol) was dropwise added into the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylicacyl chloride under stirring in the ice bath. Continuously stirring for 4h resulted in white precipitates. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The dried production weighs 1.90g (yield 60%). Anal. Calc. for C18H14N4O2: C, 67.91; H, 4.43; N, 17.60. Found: C, 67.54; H, 4.61; N, 17.39%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3442(s), 1683(s), 1507(m), 1424(s), 1285(s), 1110(w), 937(w), 878(w), 777(m), 729(m).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione(bpit)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was dropwise added into nicotinic acid (2.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a three-necked round bottom flask with constant stirring. Synthesis of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione(bpit)

SOCl2 (20ml) was dropwise added into nicotinic acid (2.45g, 20mmol) in a three-necked round bottom flask with constant stirring. The resultant pale-yellow solution was refluxed for 2h. White powder could be obtained after distilling off residue SOCl2 in a vacuum at room temperature. Then, we dissolved the powder in 10ml of dry pyridine. The pyridine solution of imidazolidine-2-thione (1.02g, 10mmol) was added to the above solution. The mixture was refluxed for 10h. The color of the solution changed to brown red and a pale brown powder precipitated. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. <ce:section-title>Crystal structure analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement were mounted on a glass fiber. All measurements were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All data were collected at a temperature of 291(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K using the <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic>–2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> scan technique and correction was applied for Lorentz-polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied. The structures were solved by the direct method and expanded using the Fourier technique. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. And hydrogen atoms were located in a different map phased on the non-hydrogen atoms and included as isotropic contributors in the final least-squares cycles. The final cycle of the full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97 crystallographic software package . Crystallographic parameters and structural refinement for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure analysis

The single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement were mounted on a glass fiber. All measurements were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). All data were collected at a temperature of 291(2)K using the ω-2θ scan technique and correction was applied for Lorentz-polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied. The structures were solved by the direct method and expanded using the Fourier technique. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. And hydrogen atoms were located in a different map phased on the non-hydrogen atoms and included as isotropic contributors in the final least-squares cycles. The final cycle of the full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the shelxl-97 crystallographic software package . Crystallographic parameters and structural refinement for 1-2 are summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>NLO measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The DMF solutions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were placed in the 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm quartz cuvette, respectively, for NLO measurements. The nonlinear refraction was measured with a linearly polarized laser light (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm; pulse widths<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd-YAG laser. The spatial profiles of the optical pulses were nearly Gaussian. The laser beam was focused with a 25-cm focal-length focusing mirror. The radius of the beam waist was measured to be 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μm (half-with at 1/<ce:italic>e</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> maximum). The interval between the laser pulses was chosen to be ∼5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s for operational convenience. The incident and transmitted pulse energies were measured simultaneously by two Laser Precision detectors (RjP-735 energy probes), which were linked to a computer by an IEEE interface. The NLO properties of the samples were manifested by moving the samples along the axis of the incident beam (<ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-direction) with respect to the focal point . An aperture of 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
NLO measurements

The DMF solutions of 1 and 2 were placed in the 1mm quartz cuvette, respectively, for NLO measurements. The nonlinear refraction was measured with a linearly polarized laser light (λ =532nm; pulse widths=8ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd-YAG laser. The spatial profiles of the optical pulses were nearly Gaussian. The laser beam was focused with a 25-cm focal-length focusing mirror. The radius of the beam waist was measured to be 35±5μm (half-with at 1/e 2 maximum). The interval between the laser pulses was chosen to be ~5s for operational convenience. The incident and transmitted pulse energies were measured simultaneously by two Laser Precision detectors (RjP-735 energy probes), which were linked to a computer by an IEEE interface. The NLO properties of the samples were manifested by moving the samples along the axis of the incident beam (Z-direction) with respect to the focal point . An aperture of 0.5mm radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.

These atoms are arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with two Hg–I bonds (2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two Hg–N bonds (2.425(8) and 2.417(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). These bond lengths are similar to those of the polymers [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bpmp, bpfp, 4,4′-azpy, bpfb, tmp and azobpy, etc. bpmp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine; bpfp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine; 4,4′-azpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-azopyridine; bpfb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene), tmp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-trimethylene dipyridine; azobpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,3′-azobispyridine , in which the separations of Hg–I ranged from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; and Hg–N are from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The I(1)–Hg(1)–I(2) bond angles (145.16(4)°) and N(4A)–Hg(1)–N(1) (96.6(3)°) are very different from the value of a regular tetrahedron (109.5°), these deviations undoubtedly occur due to the electronic and steric repulsion of the two large iodide atoms which bond to the mercury. elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH}n (1)

The crystal structure of 1 exhibits a one-dimensional zigzag framework extending along c-direction ( ). Each Hg atom coordinates with two iodide atoms and two pyridyl nitrogen donors of two bpba ligands. These atoms are arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with two Hg-I bonds (2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)Å) and two Hg-N bonds (2.425(8) and 2.417(9)Å). These bond lengths are similar to those of the polymers [HgI2(L)] n  (L=bpmp, bpfp, 4,4'-azpy, bpfb, tmp and azobpy, etc. bpmp= N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine; bpfp= N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine; 4,4'-azpy=4,4'-azopyridine; bpfb= N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene), tmp=4,4'-trimethylene dipyridine; azobpy=3,3'-azobispyridine , in which the separations of Hg-I ranged from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8)Å; and Hg-N are from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6)Å. The I(1)-Hg(1)-I(2) bond angles (145.16(4)°) and N(4A)-Hg(1)-N(1) (96.6(3)°) are very different from the value of a regular tetrahedron (109.5°), these deviations undoubtedly occur due to the electronic and steric repulsion of the two large iodide atoms which bond to the mercury. The rest of the tetrahedral angles (in the range of 100.4(2)-103.5(2)°) are much closer to their ideal value.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In the solid-state structure of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), 1-D zigzag chains are parallel to each other, between which there are two kinds of hydrogen bonds: N2–H2⋯I1 and N3–H3⋯O3, where the N are from the carboxamide groups, O3 atom is from the uncoordinated solvent CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH molecule. The distances of N–H, H⋯I and N⋯I are 0.860, 3.125 and 3.913<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, and the angle of N–H⋯I is 153.42°. While the distances of N–H, H⋯O and N⋯O are 0.860, 2.202 and 3.054<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, the angle of N–H⋯O is 169.94°. The neighboring Hg<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Hg separation within the chain is 20.506<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the shortest Hg<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Hg distance between the adjacent chains is only 5.736<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The two pyridine rings within one ligand have a little twist around the carboxamide groups due to the flexibility of the carboxamide groups, and form the dihedral angles of 14.4° and 48.5° with the central benzene ring, respectively, and the dihedral angle between them is 62.8°.</ce:para>

The distances of N-H, H⋯I and N⋯I are 0.860, 3.125 and 3.913Å, respectively, and the angle of N-H⋯I is 153.42°. elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpit)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compared with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and the reported HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bipyridine polymers [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a novel neutral binuclear metallamacrocycle with a crystallographic center of symmetry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The binuclear metallamacrocycle is composed of two Hg(II) ions, two bridging bpit ligands, and four terminal I anions. The distorted tetrahedral coordination center Hg(II) is bound to two iodide atoms and two N-donors from bpit. The Hg–I and Hg–N bond lengths are 2.6381(11) and 2.414(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, which are slightly shorter than those of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Hg–I, 2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Hg–N, 2.425(8) and 2.417(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), because of the electron-withdrawing effect of the carboxy group in the ligand bpit. On the other hand, as a result of the conformation and the rigidity of ligand bpit, the I–Hg–I and N–Hg–N bond angles (141.42° and 92.6°) are smaller than those of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (I–Hg–I, 145.16(4)° and N–Hg–N, 96.6(3)°). The bite distance of the bipyridyl ligand N(1)<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N(1B)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.189<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and separation between mercury centers Hg(1)<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Hg(1A) is 12.509<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2)

Compared with 1 and the reported HgI2-bipyridine polymers [HgI2(L)] n  , complex 2 is a novel neutral binuclear metallamacrocycle with a crystallographic center of symmetry ( ). The binuclear metallamacrocycle is composed of two Hg(II) ions, two bridging bpit ligands, and four terminal I anions. The distorted tetrahedral coordination center Hg(II) is bound to two iodide atoms and two N-donors from bpit. The Hg-I and Hg-N bond lengths are 2.6381(11) and 2.414(8)Å, respectively, which are slightly shorter than those of polymer 1 (Hg-I, 2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)Å; Hg-N, 2.425(8) and 2.417(9)Å), because of the electron-withdrawing effect of the carboxy group in the ligand bpit. On the other hand, as a result of the conformation and the rigidity of ligand bpit, the I-Hg-I and N-Hg-N bond angles (141.42° and 92.6°) are smaller than those of polymer 1 (I-Hg-I, 145.16(4)° and N-Hg-N, 96.6(3)°). The bite distance of the bipyridyl ligand N(1)…N(1B)=9.189Å and separation between mercury centers Hg(1)…Hg(1A) is 12.509Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The neutral binuclear metallamacrocycles are parallel stacked along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, and the separation of parallel aromatic rings is 7.740<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, indicating that no π–π stacking interaction participates in the formation of crystal column along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis. And the nearest intermolecular Hg<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Hg distance along the one-dimensional column is 7.746<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is much shorter than that of the intramolecular Hg<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Hg separation (12.509<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). While the closed approach of I<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>I in the adjacent bimetallic cycles is 4.196<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, indicating no significant interactions between them. The uncoordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules bond with each other forming O<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>H–O hydrogen bonds and I<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>O–H hydrogen bonds with the terminal I<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, just these intermolecular hydrogen bonds expand the one-dimensional columns to a two-dimensional supramolecular architecture as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The neutral binuclear metallamacrocycles are parallel stacked along c-axis as shown in  , and the separation of parallel aromatic rings is 7.740Å, indicating that no π-π stacking interaction participates in the formation of crystal column along the c-axis. And the nearest intermolecular Hg…Hg distance along the one-dimensional column is 7.746Å, which is much shorter than that of the intramolecular Hg…Hg separation (12.509Å). While the closed approach of I…I in the adjacent bimetallic cycles is 4.196Å, indicating no significant interactions between them. The uncoordinated H2O molecules bond with each other forming O…H-O hydrogen bonds and I…O-H hydrogen bonds with the terminal I- anions, just these intermolecular hydrogen bonds expand the one-dimensional columns to a two-dimensional supramolecular architecture as shown in  .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The bpit ligand acts as an angular “building block” in this structure: two 3-pyridine rings within one molecule forming an approximate rectangle (92.8°) with the central ring, and the dihedral angle between them is 114.0°, take on an cisoid conformation to bind to two Hg(II) ions. In addition, the dihedral angle of the two pyridine rings which coordinate with the same Hg(II) ions is 66.0°. Thus, an irregular cavity is enclosed by two bipyridyl ligands and two Hg(II) ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The bpit ligand acts as an angular "building block" in this structure: two 3-pyridine rings within one molecule forming an approximate rectangle (92.8°) with the central ring, and the dihedral angle between them is 114.0°, take on an cisoid conformation to bind to two Hg(II) ions. In addition, the dihedral angle of the two pyridine rings which coordinate with the same Hg(II) ions is 66.0°. Thus, an irregular cavity is enclosed by two bipyridyl ligands and two Hg(II) ions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Third-order nonlinear optical properties of adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The UV–Visible spectra in DMF solution show that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> display one strong absorption peak at 287 and 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, both of the two adducts have very low linear absorption ranging from 300 to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The absorptive bands could be attributed to the π–π* transitions of the ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Third-order nonlinear optical properties of adducts 1 and 2 

The UV-Visible spectra in DMF solution show that 1 and 2 display one strong absorption peak at 287 and 290nm, respectively, both of the two adducts have very low linear absorption ranging from 300 to 800nm. The absorptive bands could be attributed to the π-π* transitions of the ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It is to be pointed that our group has determined several polymeric complexes’ molecular weight in DMF solution . We found that the polymeric complexes have large molecular weight in DMF solution; that is to say, polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is intact in DMF solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is to be pointed that our group has determined several polymeric complexes' molecular weight in DMF solution . We found that the polymeric complexes have large molecular weight in DMF solution; that is to say, polymer 1 is intact in DMF solution.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The NLO properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated with 532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm laser pulse of 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ns duration in 5.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 4.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in DMF solution.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor> depicts the NLO refractive properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. We found that the two complexes possess good nonlinear optical refraction effects in DMF solutions. It is obvious that theoretical curves (solid curves) reproduce well the general pattern of observed experimental data (black dot). This fact suggests an effectively third-order characteristic for the experimentally detected NLO effects. The data show that these complexes have the similar positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity, which gives rise to self-focusing behavior.</ce:para>

It is obvious that theoretical curves (solid curves) reproduce well the general pattern of observed experimental data (black dot). This fact suggests an effectively third-order characteristic for the experimentally detected NLO effects. The data show that these complexes have the similar positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity, which gives rise to self-focusing behavior.

And they are also better than the group 10 metal alkynyl polymers (<ce:italic>γ</ce:italic> values are ranging from 10<ce:sup loc="post">−34</ce:sup> to 10<ce:sup loc="post">−35</ce:sup> at 1064<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) and some of the coordination polymers such as [M(bbbt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (bbbt<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-benzotriazole) (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, 2.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−30</ce:sup>; Mn, 1.52<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−30</ce:sup>; Cd, 1.50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−30</ce:sup>, respectively), etc.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are better than those observed in some of the organometallic compounds, semiconductors, ferrocene derivatives and fullerene, such as the γ values of organometallic compounds ranging from 10-29 to 10-31 esu, from 10-33 to 10-35 esu for ferrocene derivatives, and 1.7×10-33, 2.3×10-33, 7.5×10-34 and 1.3×10-33 esu for the semiconductors InSb, Ge, C60, and C70, respectively. And they are also better than the group 10 metal alkynyl polymers (γ values are ranging from 10-34 to 10-35 at 1064nm) and some of the coordination polymers such as [M(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n (bbbt=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole) (M=Co, 2.40×10-30; Mn, 1.52×10-30; Cd, 1.50×10-30, respectively), etc.

, [HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)]<ce:inf loc="post">

</ce:inf>
, [Cd(en)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]<ce:inf loc="post">

elements.clean_text: Both of the two adducts display self-focusing behavior, which is consistent with the previous conclusion  that the NLO properties of polymeric complexes are controlled by the valence shell structures of central metal ions; nearly all the reported polymeric complexes with d10 valence shell metal ions give self-focusing behaviors, such as organic-metal polymers [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n , [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)2] n  , [HgI2(L)] n  , [Cd(en)(NO3)2(4,4'-bpy)] n   and so on.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Furthermore, the NLO strength can be altered by the π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands. The increased π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands may enhance the extension of the electronic π-system and improve NLO properties . As far as adducts <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties. Additionally, some other factors can also contribute to the intensity of third-order optical nonlinearity, such as the orbital overlap, orbital symmetry, degree of electron delocalization, linear polarizability, etc.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the NLO strength can be altered by the π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands. The increased π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands may enhance the extension of the electronic π-system and improve NLO properties . As far as adducts 1 and 2 are concerned, the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties. Additionally, some other factors can also contribute to the intensity of third-order optical nonlinearity, such as the orbital overlap, orbital symmetry, degree of electron delocalization, linear polarizability, etc.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Up to date, lot of effort has been dedicated to explore the relationships between chemical structure and their NLO response, but many structural parameters also affect the material optical properties and the molecular complexity enhances the difficulty in finding the exact dependencies, so complimentary results on the structure-property relationship are still underway. And we believe that the study on third-order NLO properties of this kind of HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adducts may provide some available help to the design of optical materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Up to date, lot of effort has been dedicated to explore the relationships between chemical structure and their NLO response, but many structural parameters also affect the material optical properties and the molecular complexity enhances the difficulty in finding the exact dependencies, so complimentary results on the structure-property relationship are still underway. And we believe that the study on third-order NLO properties of this kind of HgI2 adducts may provide some available help to the design of optical materials.

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of ligands</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of N,N′-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was directly dissolved in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The mixture was refluxing until the white powder dissolved completely. And the residue SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was moved away under reduced pressure. The resultant 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acyl chloride was dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml dry pyridine. Then, the pyridine solution of 4-aminopyridine (1.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dropwise added into the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylicacyl chloride under stirring in the ice bath. Continuously stirring for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h resulted in white precipitates. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The dried production weighs 1.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (yield 60%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 67.91; H, 4.43; N, 17.60. Found: C, 67.54; H, 4.61; N, 17.39%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3442(s), 1683(s), 1507(m), 1424(s), 1285(s), 1110(w), 937(w), 878(w), 777(m), 729(m).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of N,N′-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione(bpit)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was dropwise added into nicotinic acid (2.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a three-necked round bottom flask with constant stirring. The resultant pale-yellow solution was refluxed for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. White powder could be obtained after distilling off residue SOCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in a vacuum at room temperature. Then, we dissolved the powder in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of dry pyridine. The pyridine solution of imidazolidine-2-thione (1.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to the above solution. The mixture was refluxed for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The color of the solution changed to brown red and a pale brown powder precipitated. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The pale yellow production weighs 1.50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (yield 48%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S: C, 57.68; H, 3.87; N, 17.94. Found: C, 57.85; H, 3.92; N, 17.65%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3433(w), 3316(w), 1672(s), 1582(m), 1470(w), 1406(s), 1363(m), 1290(s), 1225(s), 1132(m), 1026(w), 879(m), 828(w), 741(m), 706(m), 573(w).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of {[HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpba)]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.5CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">HgI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (45.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of THF was added to 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of a methanolic solution of <ce:italic>bpba</ce:italic> (31.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) at room temperature. After slow evaporation of the solvent, yellow crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained a week later. Crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are stable in the air. Yield: 65%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Synthesis of ligands

Synthesis of N,N'-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba)

1,4-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (1.66g, 10mmol) was directly dissolved in 20ml SOCl2. The mixture was refluxing until the white powder dissolved completely. And the residue SOCl2 was moved away under reduced pressure. The resultant 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acyl chloride was dissolved in 10ml dry pyridine. Then, the pyridine solution of 4-aminopyridine (1.90g, 20mmol) was dropwise added into the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylicacyl chloride under stirring in the ice bath. Continuously stirring for 4h resulted in white precipitates. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The dried production weighs 1.90g (yield 60%). Anal. Calc. for C18H14N4O2: C, 67.91; H, 4.43; N, 17.60. Found: C, 67.54; H, 4.61; N, 17.39%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3442(s), 1683(s), 1507(m), 1424(s), 1285(s), 1110(w), 937(w), 878(w), 777(m), 729(m).

Synthesis of N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione(bpit)

SOCl2 (20ml) was dropwise added into nicotinic acid (2.45g, 20mmol) in a three-necked round bottom flask with constant stirring. The resultant pale-yellow solution was refluxed for 2h. White powder could be obtained after distilling off residue SOCl2 in a vacuum at room temperature. Then, we dissolved the powder in 10ml of dry pyridine. The pyridine solution of imidazolidine-2-thione (1.02g, 10mmol) was added to the above solution. The mixture was refluxed for 10h. The color of the solution changed to brown red and a pale brown powder precipitated. The precipitates were filtered under reduced pressure, and washed by water and methanol, respectively. The pale yellow production weighs 1.50g (yield 48%). Anal. Calc. for C15H12N4O2S: C, 57.68; H, 3.87; N, 17.94. Found: C, 57.85; H, 3.92; N, 17.65%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3433(w), 3316(w), 1672(s), 1582(m), 1470(w), 1406(s), 1363(m), 1290(s), 1225(s), 1132(m), 1026(w), 879(m), 828(w), 741(m), 706(m), 573(w).

Synthesis of {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1)

HgI2 (45.5mg, 0.1mmol) in 5ml of THF was added to 5ml of a methanolic solution of bpba (31.8mg, 0.1mmol) at room temperature. After slow evaporation of the solvent, yellow crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained a week later. Crystals of 1 are stable in the air. Yield: 65%. Anal. Calc. for C19.5H20HgI2N4O3.5: C, 28.53; H, 2.46; N, 6.83. Found: C, 28.47; H, 2.51; N 6.88%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3346(m), 1694(s), 1587(s), 1508(s), 1420(s), 1291(s), 1011(m), 877(w), 826(s), 720(w).

Synthesis of [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2)

DMF solution (2ml) of bpit (31.2mg, 0.1mmol) was added dropwise into the THF (8ml) of HgI2 (45.5mg, 0.1mmol), the resulting clear solution was made to stand at room temperature. Light-yellow crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after standing for one week. Crystals of 2 were also stable in the air. Yield: 50%. Anal. Calc. for C15H11HgI2N4O5S: C, 22.14; H, 1.36; N, 6.89. Found: C, 22.09; H, 1.39; N 6.82%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3439(s), 2921(s), 2854(m), 1638(s), 1458(m), 1383(m), 1291(m), 1227(m), 1096(m), 535(m).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

One-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2) were prepared based on linear and angular bipyridine ligands, respectively. Third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2in DMF solution show that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively. And the result shows that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

Abstract

Two bis(pyridyl) ligands: N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (bpit) have been designed and synthesized. Self-assembly of the linear ligand bpba and angular ligand bpit with HgI2 results in a one-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and a binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that in the crystal structure of 1 the linear ligand bpba is in transoid conformation, while in the crystal structure of 2 the angular ligand bpit coordinates with HgI2 in cisoid conformation, the different geometries of the two ligands attribute to forming the dissimilar frameworks of two HgI2 adducts. The determination of third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2 in DMF solution shows that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are calculated to be 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively, which are comparable to those of some NLO materials. And the result indicates that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

NLO measurements

The DMF solutions of 1 and 2 were placed in the 1mm quartz cuvette, respectively, for NLO measurements. The nonlinear refraction was measured with a linearly polarized laser light (λ =532nm; pulse widths=8ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd-YAG laser. The spatial profiles of the optical pulses were nearly Gaussian. The laser beam was focused with a 25-cm focal-length focusing mirror. The radius of the beam waist was measured to be 35±5μm (half-with at 1/e 2 maximum). The interval between the laser pulses was chosen to be ~5s for operational convenience. The incident and transmitted pulse energies were measured simultaneously by two Laser Precision detectors (RjP-735 energy probes), which were linked to a computer by an IEEE interface. The NLO properties of the samples were manifested by moving the samples along the axis of the incident beam (Z-direction) with respect to the focal point . An aperture of 0.5mm radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH}n (1)

The crystal structure of 1 exhibits a one-dimensional zigzag framework extending along c-direction ( ). Each Hg atom coordinates with two iodide atoms and two pyridyl nitrogen donors of two bpba ligands. These atoms are arranged in a severely distorted tetrahedron with two Hg-I bonds (2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)Å) and two Hg-N bonds (2.425(8) and 2.417(9)Å). These bond lengths are similar to those of the polymers [HgI2(L)] n  (L=bpmp, bpfp, 4,4'-azpy, bpfb, tmp and azobpy, etc. bpmp= N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine; bpfp= N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine; 4,4'-azpy=4,4'-azopyridine; bpfb= N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene), tmp=4,4'-trimethylene dipyridine; azobpy=3,3'-azobispyridine , in which the separations of Hg-I ranged from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8)Å; and Hg-N are from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6)Å. The I(1)-Hg(1)-I(2) bond angles (145.16(4)°) and N(4A)-Hg(1)-N(1) (96.6(3)°) are very different from the value of a regular tetrahedron (109.5°), these deviations undoubtedly occur due to the electronic and steric repulsion of the two large iodide atoms which bond to the mercury. The rest of the tetrahedral angles (in the range of 100.4(2)-103.5(2)°) are much closer to their ideal value.

Crystal structure of [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2)

Compared with 1 and the reported HgI2-bipyridine polymers [HgI2(L)] n  , complex 2 is a novel neutral binuclear metallamacrocycle with a crystallographic center of symmetry ( ). The binuclear metallamacrocycle is composed of two Hg(II) ions, two bridging bpit ligands, and four terminal I anions. The distorted tetrahedral coordination center Hg(II) is bound to two iodide atoms and two N-donors from bpit. The Hg-I and Hg-N bond lengths are 2.6381(11) and 2.414(8)Å, respectively, which are slightly shorter than those of polymer 1 (Hg-I, 2.6690(12) and 2.6608(13)Å; Hg-N, 2.425(8) and 2.417(9)Å), because of the electron-withdrawing effect of the carboxy group in the ligand bpit. On the other hand, as a result of the conformation and the rigidity of ligand bpit, the I-Hg-I and N-Hg-N bond angles (141.42° and 92.6°) are smaller than those of polymer 1 (I-Hg-I, 145.16(4)° and N-Hg-N, 96.6(3)°). The bite distance of the bipyridyl ligand N(1)…N(1B)=9.189Å and separation between mercury centers Hg(1)…Hg(1A) is 12.509Å.

Third-order nonlinear optical properties of adducts 1 and 2 

The UV-Visible spectra in DMF solution show that 1 and 2 display one strong absorption peak at 287 and 290nm, respectively, both of the two adducts have very low linear absorption ranging from 300 to 800nm. The absorptive bands could be attributed to the π-π* transitions of the ligands.

The NLO properties of 1 and 2 are investigated with 532nm laser pulse of 8ns duration in 5.89×10-4 moldm-3 for 1 and 4.92×10-4 moldm-3 for 2 in DMF solution.

   depicts the NLO refractive properties of 1 and 2, respectively. We found that the two complexes possess good nonlinear optical refraction effects in DMF solutions. It is obvious that theoretical curves (solid curves) reproduce well the general pattern of observed experimental data (black dot). This fact suggests an effectively third-order characteristic for the experimentally detected NLO effects. The data show that these complexes have the similar positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity, which gives rise to self-focusing behavior.

It can be seen from (a) that the difference of valley-peak positions, ΔZ V-P, is 10.69mm, the difference between normalized transmittance values at valley and peak portions, ΔT V-P, is 0.17. The refractive index n 2 of 1 is calculated to be 9.14×10-18 m2 W-1. For 2, ΔZ V-P and ΔT V-P are 10.33mm and 0.22, respectively ((b)), n 2 value is 1.18×10-17 m2 W-1.

In accordance with the n 2 values, the effective third-order susceptibility χ (3) can be calculated by   |   χ   ( 3 )   | =   cn   0   2     n   2   / 80 π   and the χ (3) values of 1 and 2 are 2.23×10-11 esu and 2.88×10-11 esu, respectively. The corresponding modulus of the hyperpolarizability γ was obtained from |γ|= χ (3)/NF 4, where N is the number density of a compound (concentration); F 4 =3 is the local field correction factor. The γ values of 1 and 2 are calculated to be 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively.

The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are better than those observed in some of the organometallic compounds, semiconductors, ferrocene derivatives and fullerene, such as the γ values of organometallic compounds ranging from 10-29 to 10-31 esu, from 10-33 to 10-35 esu for ferrocene derivatives, and 1.7×10-33, 2.3×10-33, 7.5×10-34 and 1.3×10-33 esu for the semiconductors InSb, Ge, C60, and C70, respectively. And they are also better than the group 10 metal alkynyl polymers (γ values are ranging from 10-34 to 10-35 at 1064nm) and some of the coordination polymers such as [M(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n (bbbt=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole) (M=Co, 2.40×10-30; Mn, 1.52×10-30; Cd, 1.50×10-30, respectively), etc.

<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The data were assessed by dividing the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the closed aperture configuration by the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the open aperture configuration. The black dots are the experimental data, and the solids curve is the theoretical fit. (a) The self-focusing effects of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in 5.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution at 532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. (b) The self-focusing effects of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in 4.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution at 532<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  The data were assessed by dividing the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the closed aperture configuration by the normalized Z-scan data obtained under the open aperture configuration. The black dots are the experimental data, and the solids curve is the theoretical fit. (a) The self-focusing effects of 1 in 5.89×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution at 532nm. (b) The self-focusing effects of 2 in 4.92×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution at 532nm.

metadata.title: Self-assembly and third-order optical properties of HgI2 with linear and angular bipyridine ligands
